bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.A. Sweet, May 3, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] requests data on the mosquito Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to E.A. Sweet, May 3, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
May 3, 1923.
Book
Haiwai
Australia
Surgeon E. A. Sweet,
Chief Quarantine Officer,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Honolulu, Hawaii.
Dear Doctor Sweet:
div1.p:
I am asked to write a paper for the Australian Health authorities
discussing the chance of the introduction of yellow fever from the
West Coast of South America into that country directly or via South-
estern Asia.

As Hawaii would naturally be a half way stopping point for this
I would be much your debtor if you will give me all the data you
can on the infestation of these islands--the large sea-ports es-
pecially (Honolulu and ?)--with the mosquito Aedes (Stegomyia) ae-
gypti.

I was under orders, in 1911, for Hawaii for the purpose of in-
stituting a campaign in their control. I know the campaign was un-
dertaken, but have no idea as to the present status of aegypti infestation
in Hawaii.
